captions.text:
One thing that's astounding about Einstein's
publications in 1905 is that they spanned

such a large breadth of physics: after illuminating
the quantum nature of light by explaining

the photoelectric effect in March, in April
he turned to something apparently more mundane:

In particular, if you look at tiny particles
in water, or dust motes in the air, you'll

see that they jitter about in a very odd and
random way. That is, it appears odd and random

unless you believe that the air or water itself
is made up of even smaller particles called

atoms or molecules, which just bounce off
of each other according to very simple rules.

This is called Brownian motion, despite the
fact that botanist Brown wasn't the first

to discover it, and similarly Einstein wan't
the first to describe it mathematically…

but he did draw the conclusion that the mathematical
description of Brownian motion is evidence

for the existence of atoms even if you can't
see them directly, and then he cleverly derived

how big atoms should be just based on how
much the Brownian particles move.

That's like measuring the size of a penguin
just by looking at how icebergs jiggle. Talk

title: Albert Einstein: The Size and Existence of Atoms

comments.text:
Einstein's paper was probably just the final nudge for general acceptance 
of the atomic theory. Boltzmann's development of statistical mechanics to 
explain/understand thermodynamics and the perfect gas law was a major 
driver. Boltzmann, by the way, committed suicide because others would not 
accept his evidence of atoms.

Ben Franklin's work on the spreading of a tiny drop of oil to cover a large 
area on a pond, more than 100 yrs earlier, could have made him a truly 
great scientist (instead of just a famous one). He simply needed to divide 
the volume of the drop by the area of the pond and then speculate on what 
that tiny thickness meant. That division was all that was needed to have 
made Franklin one of the fathers of atomic theory!﻿

comments.text:
+TheShamansQuestion Early on Special Relativity appeared not to work with 
QM. However, Richard Feynman and others developed a rigorous theory that 
united SR and QM. I've studied Quantum Field Theory and other Relativistic 
Quantum Theories and they work very well. GR has yet to be merged with QM.
comments.author: dutchrjen

comments.text:
+dutchrjen I really like your discussion on "intrinsic" things, as a 
philosophy student. They are quite the problem! :)

I was lectured in a course roughly about what QM at the time of Einstein, 
but more in a conceptual matter, so I can't speak for sure about what 
you've said regarding quantum field theory though I've heard of it (I was 
lead to believe SR and QM weren't quite fitting perhaps by vague sources, 
but I'm really glad you do say they work since I believe Einstein was smart 
enough and open-minded enough to realise his biases). I'm writing this 
comment because I liked what you've spoken about even though I can't 
dispute/support you.
comments.author: TheShamansQuestion

comments.text:
+Urameshi Yusuke " Einsteins macro version of the world in relativity, a 
world that can be calculated and makes predictions in the real world"

Not really true. Special Relativity and Quantum Mechanics merge together 
very well to make a very well understood theory (mathematically at least as 
no one intuitively understands it). Special Relativity works extremely well 
on the tiny and it has been very successful and so has Quantum Mechanics. 
Quantum Field Theory (the full merging of quantum theory with special 
relativity) scales up to the macroscopic VERY well. That is the limit as 
any system becomes large smoothly goes from quantum like to classical (as 
long as speeds are much less than c).  

General Relativity is the less understood and odd one out. We haven't done 
that many experiments on this one because gravity is so weak. General 
Relativity doesn't scale down to the microscopic very well and super strong 
gravity fields like blackholes don't mesh well with the quantum world. We 
also haven't explained why particles have certain masses or why certain 
constants are certain values. Or for that matter anything else that we 
simply label "intrinsic." Intrinsic (intrinsic mass, intrinsic spin, 
intrinsic charge, intrinsic baryon number, etc) is just another word for "I 
have no fucking clue."

The cool thing about science is at some point everything is based on 
"intrinsic" things we just accept as true but we will never know for sure 
if there is reasoning behind those "intrinsic" things. (All logic is based 
on fundamental premises we just universally accept as true).
comments.author: dutchrjen

comments.text:
+owbu nothing to do with religion, he hated the idea of the randomness 
quantum mechanics implies in nature. At least that's what my understanding 
is :) also he tried but was never able to unite quantum physics and macro 
physics. I believe that's what he was working on when he died! The 
all-encompassing theory of everything.
comments.author: James M

comments.text:
+owbu no, he wasn't really opposed at all. He actually helped provide some 
of the initial research and was a huge proponent of there actually being a 
quantum world that acted differently then our own. Einstein wasn't 
religious either. He was a Jew, yes, but did not practice the religion. He 
was opposed to SOME of what quantum physics proposed because some of it 
contradicted his larger view of physics that he spent his entire life 
creating. The same view of physics we use today in general and special 
relativity. But today physics is generally separated into two types: 
Einsteins macro version of the world in relativity, a world that can be 
calculated and makes predictions in the real world...and then theres the 
quantum view of the world which deals with much less understood things. The 
problem is that the nature of particles at a quantum scale doesn't really 
conform to how we see regular matter act on a macro scale. Quantum physics 
literally breaks the rules of regular physics in some aspects, like 
particles teleporting through energy barriers, or particles occupying the 
same point in space, or particles traveling faster than light perhaps. And 
quantum physics was in its infancy when Einstein developed relativity. As 
you can see in this video, he had no doubt there was an entire world 
existing beyond our sight, the quantum world, and he knew it would 
contradict his own theories even then, but he still helped promote it 
because he was genuinely intrigued. He was truly a scientific man
comments.author: Urameshi Yusuke

This is an invitation to see an artist model of the physics of ‘time’ as a 
physical process. In this theory the physics of quantum mechanics 
represents the physics of ‘time’ as a physical process. The spontaneous 
absorption and emission of light (wave particle duality) is forming a blank 
canvas that we can interact with turning the possible into the actual! Time 
is an emergent property with the future coming into existence photon by 
photon relative to the actions of the atoms.
